vectors.text: From sinners to degenerates: the medicalization of morality in the 19th century ABSTRACT This article explores two very different forms in which immoral conduct was problematized over the course of the 19th century. It does this by contrasting the sexual purity politics of the Vice Society and the medializtion of morality as ‘moral insanity’. Early in the century the Vice Society promoted coercive legislation with the aim of ‘suppress-ing vice’. From mid-century, moral insanity theories sought to grapple with vice by disaggregating ‘moral’ from other forms of insanity. These two movements had quite distinct and incompatible lines of development; and they never overtly engaged with each other. The article makes its key argument by demonstrating the way in which such dissimilar trajectories came together towards the end of the century in the ‘moral hygiene’ movement, mobilizing discourses of ‘degeneration’ (and ‘feeblemindedness’) with projects promoting sexual purity. INTRODUCTION Hitherto the cultivation of the moral faculty has been the busines s of parents, schoolmasters and divines. But . . . the improvement and extensions of this principle should be equally the business of th e legis- lator – the natural philosophers – and the physicians. . . . [T]his encou r- ages us to undertake experiments for the improvement of morals. (Rush, 1839: 24) Attempts to govern morals pervade the history of human societies . Such projects have taken many forms from attempts to impose religious u nifor- mity through uncompromising coercion to gentler but no less insi stent efforts to cultivate manners. Moral regulation may operate throu gh the exter- nal action of agents and institutions upon subjects and it may sti mulate sub- jects to act upon their own conduct. So pervasive have such projects b een that it is unwise to seek to pronounce any general sequence of forms of mora l governance. Nevertheless certain important shifts are identiﬁ able. This article traces one signiﬁcant transition, that from governance organized around moral codes deriving their authority from religious doctrine to a distinctive medicalization of moral rule that occurred in western societies in the middle of the 19th century. In order to provide a provisional location of th is process we may note that it is congruent with the transition identiﬁed by Foucault from the attempt to impose binding moral codes rooted in some tr aditional authority to mechanisms regulating behavior according to a divi sion between the normal and the pathological. Once the normal was deﬁned it was but a short step to the stipula tion of norms. Norms of conduct are elaborated by a variety of what may be called experts of normality, who simultaneously deﬁne the attributes of the normal individual and exclude the miscreant as one who deviates from th ese norms by committing individualized transgressions. The ambiguity of th is process should be noted in the coexistence of the duality of norms: that which is normal or average and that which is desirable became merged. The norm is that which is average and, at the same time, desirable. In brief, the transition is from one focused on sin to one organized around the distinction between the normal and the pathological. The transition from codes to norms has an unmistakable historical dimension, but this is not such that one form dies when the other i s born. Both forms can be traced backwards and forwards and they appear and reappear in various combinations. However, attempts to impose moral codes require the existence of some privileged source of authority. Such a strategy was doomed to fail once the hegemony of traditional authority falte red. For example, in England the attempt to construct a unitary religious authority (Church of England), despite the consecration of the church–state link, wa s already a failure by the end of the 17th century. In this article we focus attention on the discovery or invention of m oral insanity, which in the early Victorian period played a signiﬁcant role in the emergence of psychiatric medical intervention in the never-endin g project of the improvement of morals. In order to situate this developmen t we contrast it with the example of the ‘Vice Society’, a late 18th- and early 19th-cent ury English movement that sought to reimpose a traditional moral code.It is central to our argument that the shift from moral code to moral ins anity should not be understood as a manifestation of an Enlightenmen t process of the displacement of religion by medicine. Rather we seek to draw att ention to the complex processes which involve a distinct hybridity in the g overn- ance of morality; that is, the practices and discourses put into action result from quite distinct and often contradictory elements. There is no simple chronology of stages of regulatory projects; rath er they overlap, collide and reappear in different guises. It is necessary t o attend to the way in which the management of virtue and vice has been conteste d and divided between a range of different authorities, religious, ped agogic, medical and political. It is not that one form displaced another in sequen ce, but rather that different conﬁgurations in combination came to the fore; such com bi- natory authorities were generally not the result of any concerted s trategy, but rather were ushered in by the cultural preoccupations of the period. We will argue that at a time when one might expect to ﬁnd the culmination of the displacement of religion by the medical and, in particula r, the psychological sciences, by the end of the 19th century (as we seek to docu- ment) an alliance had developed between moral codes rooted in th e Christ- ian tradition and the ‘new’ medical and psychological discourses . This alliance took the form of the ‘social and moral hygiene’ movement wh ich played a signiﬁcant role in the ﬁelds of both moral regulation and public hygiene in the early years of the 20th century. Before we embark on an historical account of the contrasting forms of moral regulation there are a number of conceptual or theoretical issues that serve to situate the approach adopted. It is necessary to consider some of the more signiﬁcant concepts that form our ﬁeld of inquiry such as ‘the mo ral’, ‘the will’, ‘character’, the targets of regulation and, ﬁnally, the medicalization of the governance of the diseases of the will. The moral Character and the governance of the will Second, at the core of the treatment we adopt is the importance of att ending to the role played by shifting conceptions of ‘the will’ which appear s in a variety of guises, the most important of which are ‘the soul’ and ‘ch aracter’. The ‘will’ and the ‘soul’ designated an essentialist concepti on of the interior condition of the person. The will was loosely associated with the m ind and with reason while the soul was pure essence, deriving its signi ﬁcance precisely from its imaginary summation of a composite of the human interiori ty. The will was counterposed to the ‘passions’ conceived as a set of pote ntial incli- nations and appetites (greed, envy, etc.) that were seen as endemic. W ithin religious discourse they were the legacy of original sin, but in mor e natural- istic discourses they were conceived as natural inclinations, inst incts, not inherently evil, but which became so in excess. The will is capable of b eing worked upon, of being controlled, held in check, or even overcome. It has t o be trained to master the passions; civilization required a const ant despotism over oneself (Valverde, 1996). ‘Character’ differs in that it provides a means of conceptualizing t he link between the human interior and the exterior. It is a set of quali ties detectable through their behavioral manifestations. This is particularl y evident when character regimes emphasize their external stigmata as when th e Victorians promoted a masculinity that announced itself with the proverbia l straight back and ‘stiff upper lip’. Those who have character have the right to procure the reform of those who cannot or are unwilling to improve themse lves; this is particularly evident in the despotism over children. Despite their variant conceptualizations the will, the passion s, the soul and the character share the crucial attribute of being suitable object s of govern- ance; they can be worked upon, trained, developed and thus reformed. It is of particular signiﬁcance to note that the governance of the will can be effected either by individuals themselves or by others; that is, the ir govern- ance can be both internal and external. The targets of regulation Medicalization It is not easy to specify exactly when psychiatry as a distinct branch of med i- cine emerged, but it appears to be clear that the fusion of psychology a nd medicine surfaced as a specialized knowledge by the mid-19th century. Drawing hard and fast dividing lines between medicine, psycholog y and psy- chiatry is particularly difﬁcult due to the overlap between the rap idly chang- ing delineation of subﬁelds in this period. Moral insanity prov ides just such an example of blurred expert knowledge categories. For example, e xperts identiﬁed themselves by a host of professional demarcations and areas of expertise such as mental science, medical psychology (or psychological m edi- cine), neurology and pathology, and as clinicians, insanitists, psychi atrists, alienists and physicians. Medical discourses on moral insanity in large part operated tra nsversely; that is, outside the boundedness of political-geographical bou ndaries of nation-states. Work in the ﬁeld of moral insanity was shared by a transcon-tinental psycho-medical community who through publications, professional associations and the like, shared knowledge not necessarily according to geographical location; similarly practitioners shared advances in treatment practices. Thus one ﬁnds moral insanity experts citing the work of th eir transatlantic counterparts. As Berrios (1996) notes, there existed genuine ‘free communication’ between experts in the human sciences. At the birth of what came to be designated as the psychological science s there existed a set of techniques for collecting and conﬁning those whose immoral conduct could, if left unaddressed, cause social disorder. Social danger increasingly came to be seen in violations of the norms of respectable society. These disciplinary strategies for identifying transgres sors would later be codiﬁed by the psychological disciplines as ‘defects of character’. As psychological expertise distinguished itself from the wider category of medicine it generated a know-how about the normal individual through the study of the abnormal individual; the patient provided access to the constructing of the ‘normal’. An alternative thesis suggests that it was not so much a matter o f restraining those that threatened social peace. Rather the concern to diag nose what came to be termed moral insanity was an instance of what Foucault cal led a ‘dividing practice’, which served not merely to distinguish those who were deemed to pose a threat to social order, but to ‘divide’ such persons from the population at large. This in turn facilitates the use of technique s of separation, identiﬁcation, exclusion and institutionalization against th ose who fall outside the boundaries of moralized sociability. Like other forms of moralizing discourse, psychology focused attention on the quest to activate self-control. This is captured in a classic form ulation by William Clouston: The highest aim of mental hygiene should be to increase the power s of mental inhibition amongst all men and women. Control is the ba sis of all law and the cement of every social system among men and women, without which it would go to pieces. (1906: 139) Morality increasingly became codiﬁed through scientiﬁc discourses (Baker, Porter and Porter, 1993). The medicalization of morality and the nat - uralization of the moral realm were perhaps never so fully attend ed to as in the 19th century. While the debate around degeneracy was at the core, th ere was a signiﬁcant variety of other issues that involved the relat ionship between morals and medicine, such as the controversy surrounding masturb ation (Hare, 1962: Hunt, 1998; Neuman, 1975). Impassioned debates occurred over the proper response to the slowly accumulating knowledge concerni ng sexually transmitted diseases, which pitted regulationists, w ho secured the controversial Contagious Diseases Acts 1864–9 that imposed medical in spec- tion on suspected prostitutes, and the anti-regulationists, w ho opposed the legislation, condemning it as a tacit acceptance of vice, and secured it s repeal in 1883. During these controversies medical opinion shifted from the r egula- tionist to the anti-regulationist camp (Ogborn, 1993; F. B. Smith, 1971; Walkowitz, 1980). The emergent antagonism between science and religion was partially reconciled in the 19th century through the endorsement of theological morality by the medical profession. The rapprochement took two primary forms:first, by the use of scientific knowledge to support Christian morality as the basis for conceptions both of a presumed natural social order and of individual character and the virtues; second, by medicine’s striving to explain the moral constitution of human beings through a materialist medical science. The project of applying scientific knowledge to the moral realm was viewedas integral to accomplishing the great work of man’s deliverance from the evils that constantly beset his pathway. . . . When a man can fully comprehend the fact that most, if not all, the so-called ‘sins’ of life are due to the manner of physical construction[,] . . . the various appetites and passions which have been the cause of so much sorrow in the world, science could deliver man from evil. (Williamson, 1898: 12–13) One of the goals of medicine was to provide scientiﬁc legitimation to the professional enterprise of extending theological views of character, vice and the passions to the explanation of the pathology of immoral souls. Physicians, Moreau argued, do not ‘intend to exculpate the miserable beings addicted to the base vice; we would have them to be considered not as true male factors, but as diseased persons’ (1884: 369). It was in this context that a signiﬁcan t change occurred; corrupt souls came to be viewed as suffering from a mor al pathology that was to be understood as a form of disease or degene ration. Such frameworks were deployed in the service of governing what was perceived as the growing vices of disruptive industrialization and the much- feared growth of the city. This medical ﬁxation on the link between p assion, vice and character is most thoroughly demonstrated by the inventi on of ‘moral insanity’. Psychiatry’s recognition of this form of mental dis ease is of importance since it was thus called upon to assist normalization by providing a science of morality, which transcended but did not displace rel igious doctrine. Those who came to designate their specialization in the psycho- logical ﬁeld were an important component of ‘the proliferatings cientiﬁc experts of the moral order’ (Rose, 1999: 76). Projects of urban reform became increasingly concerned to promote well- ordered social space judged by criteria of morality and public health. An increasingly dense grid of norms of conduct was imposed over urbans pace that operated by regulating behaviour according to the divisio n of the normal and the pathological. It needs to be borne in mind that the disti nction between the normal and the pathological was unstable; what the moral reformers were often unaware of was that practices that they took to b e pathological, were already well on the way to becoming ‘normal’. Fo r example, the conduct of heterosocial encounters of the young was stea dily slipping away from the governance of rigid rules of chaperons and ‘courting’ was increasingly taking place outside direct familial surveillance. The rules of civility were producing new dividing practices betwee n those within and those outside civility that were linked to a whole set of new inventions for disciplining those whose transgressions were an affro nt to the order of proper comportment, decency and propriety. We ﬁrst trace these cont ested spaces and terrains in the history of the ‘Vice Society’ to which we no w turn. Thereafter we then explore the intervention of the emergent ps ychiatric forms of medical knowledge and its invention of moral insanity. THE VICE SO CIETY: MORALS IN AN AGE OF ANXIETY The intensiﬁcation of projects of moral regulation in early 19th-century Britain reﬂects the interacting social, economic and political anxieties of the propertied classes generated by the dual revolutions, the Industrial Revolution and the French Revolution. There was escalating concern with the moral conditions of the stirring mass of the working and non-worki ng poor. The respectable classes experienced deep apprehensions about the declining hegemony of the traditional authority of the social, political and religious establishments. They responded with a disparate array of projects of moral regulation. In the early 19th century the preoccupation with instituting a more rigorous moral governance had an explicitly political context. De ep fore- bodings manifested themselves in a preoccupation with the condi tions of the poor that took form in the early investigations of ‘the social question’.2There emerged a variety of societies and associations that strove to pu rsue projects that sought to govern what was still termed the ‘manners’ of th e populace. The institutional expressions were legion. The burgeoning o f civil society worked in two directions. On the one hand it stimulated state formation providing an infrastructure for the expansion of a dense system of admi nistration while, on the other hand, as civil society became more dense it was in creasingly able to act independently of the state apparatuses. Two forms of civil associations serve to illustrate these processes. The ﬁrst concerns policing and the second philanthropy. The propertied classes became increasingly concerned about problems of social order. Local societies, characteristically called ‘Associations for the Prosecuti on of Felons’, were formed as private organizations of property-owners, combin- ing to arrest and prosecute offenders. In brief they were civil societ y protecting its sectional interests and coming to the aid of the state . The second category of associations may be loosely labelled philanthropic; it embraced many societies that were overtly religious, distributing pious tracts or enforcing Sunday observance. More secular forms of philanthropy invo lved a distinctive engagement with an urban experience. The towns an d cities of this new world were perceived to be full of moral danger and an ever-present risk of disorder. The practice of philanthropy necessitated the expl oration of the unknown, the fetid alleys and tenements of the towns from which the middle classes were increasingly separated both physically and emotionally. The key ﬁgure was the pauper and the condition of pauperism, captured in the abiding concern with overcrowding, linked to both emergent medical ideas about contagious diseases and implicit sexual discourses about excess in general and incest in particular. Philanthropy involved a distinctively new form of personal contact, that of ‘visiting’. The visit to the homes of the poor was to be the distinctive contribution of an expanding participation by middle-class women in moral surveillance. This emergent philanthropy was structured by a complex involvement with debates that revolved around a tangled engagement between moral and social environmentalism. Moral environmentalism emphasized the moral deficiencies that stemmed from an impaired religious faith or a weakened capacity for self-restraint. In contrast social environmentalism viewed moral deﬁciencies as resulting from a dverse social conditions, poor housing and sanitation, lack of education, and – more radically – low wages. These contrasting positions rarely presented th emselves as a simple opposition between social and moral environmentalism. Both strands exhibited a tension between coercion and improvement that played themselves out both within organizations and in the debates between them. The reform of manners by proclamation The ‘Vice Society’ had its origins in a precursor, the ‘Proclamatio n Society’ established by the inﬂuential ‘High Church’ evangelical reformer, William Wilberforce, today largely remembered for his role in the anti-slavery movement. He believed in what he called the ‘grand law of subordinati on’: that everyone should know their allotted place in the social order. Wilberforce in association with a number of peers and church dignitaries persuaded George III to issue a Proclamation in 1787 ‘For the Encouragement of Piety and Virtue and for Preventing and Punishing of Vice, Pro- faneness and Immorality’.3They then set about organizing an association to effect the enforcement of this proclamation. The proclamation invoked a traditional providential doctrine of securing divine pleasure by suppressing immorality. It contained prohibitions on playing dice and cards; it called for the suppression of all gaming-houses and all licentious publications; it also required church attendance. The Vice Society In 1802 another moral reform association was established, the ‘Society for the Suppression of Vice’, subsequently referred to as the ‘Vice Society’ . The new project was conceived as a different kind of organization. It was concern ed to draw the respectable metropolitan classes into concerted action at a time when fear of impending national disaster was widespread. It was formed in a climate of patriotic anti-radical wartime fervour. Fear of the idle ness and criminality of the lower orders was articulated through discours es of degeneration and demoralization. The Vice Society was an elite fraternity that brought together the urban professional and commercial classes. Its early members included Anglican vicars, ﬁve lawyers, two booksellers, two surgeons and a number of clerks. The society aspired to a wider membership; it reported having 200 members in 1802, 561 members by early 1803, 1,200 by the end of 1804. It remained largely anonymous; its pronouncements were generally made in the name of ‘the Society’ and there were no visible prominent named members. Their activities underwent distinct shifts over time. In the early years their project was concerned with popular culture linked to aims of patriotism and ‘improving’ society that expressed itself in a prosecution stra tegy which targetted two signiﬁcantly different groups, Sunday street-traders and political radicals. The preoccupation with Sunday observance and blasphemy w as a coherent expression of the general contest that the evangelical s saw themselves engaged in against the forces of secular rationalism; hence they perceived an intimate connection between religious blasphemy and political sedition. In the period after the Napoleonic wars their attention became increasingly focused on blasphemy and obscenity. They had two distinct targets. The ﬁrst were the publishers of radical texts and papers; the second were t he street- sellers of sexually explicit prints and songs. Thereby political radicals were tarred with the brush of obscenity. The society mounted a series of prosecution against the Paineite freethinker Richard Carlile, Paine’s publisher. While the society retained the rhetoric of moral reform, it had become a politically partisan organization more concerned to suppress radicalism than everyday immoralities. In the ﬁnal phase of its existence from the 1830s the society largely disappeared from public view and became a pressure group concerned to stimulate the legislation of morality. It retained some of its prosecu torial functions, becoming a semi-ofﬁcial enforcement agency on behalf of literary decency. Its only notable achievement was in securing the passage of the Ob scene Publications Act in 1857. The main impact of this statute was to regularize the existing common law offences facilitating prosecutions and pro viding increased police powers to search for and conﬁscate obscene material. At ﬁrst the Act was used against street obscenity, but there were a series of prosecutions of artistic and scientiﬁc works between 1869 and 1880. The society’s attempt to secure further legislation provoked mass action agai nst measures that attacked working-class life and leisure; in 1854 attempts to restrict Sunday drinking were abandoned when they stirred mass demonstrations. The targets of moral regulation The society deﬁned its targets as crimes injurious to public morals. However, it recognized that the enforcement of such offences could result in accusa - tions of ofﬁciousness and thus generate resistance. Yet its members’ evangelical enthusiasm often got the better of such sober calculation. They evinced the persisting concern of the respectable classes with two closely related issues, popular recreations and Sunday observance. Place s of public entertainment and public houses persistently elicited outrage at the indecencies they ﬂaunted. As a result of the diffusion of wage-labour, Sunday became the occasion for recreational and family activities. The society launched periodic attacks on the London fairs as sites of unrestrained popular recreation. There were other targets set out in the society’s manifesto: profa ne swearing was always an extension of Sunday observance and blasphemy; the members launched periodic assaults on gambling and lotteries. It is important to note that while they included the suppression of disorderly houses and brothels, they launched only occasional prosecutions and their rhe toric about immorality made only passing reference to sexual transgressions. The society had to defend its strategy against attack from disparate sources. Its members’ concern to sustain relations with the political establishment led them to seek to deﬂect the conservative criticism, epitomized by William Cobbett’s objection that the society was ‘a standing conspiracy against the quiet and tranquility of society’ (Roberts, 1983: 168). On the other hand they confronted more radical criticism, most famously by Sydney Smith, that th e society should rename itself the ‘Society for Suppressing the Vices of persons whose income does not exceed £500 per annum’ (S. Smith, 1809: 342). He challenged the hypocrisy of the society’s justiﬁcation for not prosecu ting rich proﬂigates on the grounds that the poor commit their vices in public, while the rich do so in private. Beyond coercive moral reform? The Vice Society was a project devoted to moral reform from above. As a small exclusive organization it made no effort to recruit a mass me mbership or to communicate with those it sought to reform. The society made only perfunctory efforts to legitimate its project or to address its tar gets. Its tracts merely asserted the moral deﬁciencies of the nation and repeated the self- evident necessity of suppressing immorality. Its members had no hesitation, during periods of heightened political instability, in becoming an extension of the coercive apparatus of the state. Two inferences can be drawn. First, is that the task that preoccupied t he society was to sustain contact with the Establishment. Second, is th at the lower orders were to be compelled to virtue rather than to be persuaded of the desirability of moral reform. Thus moral regulation in the early Victorian period was a narrowly conceived coercive strategy. Although the participants had links to the ﬂourishing and expanding philanthropic movement the projects remained distinct and largely unconnected. As a result the Vice Society stayed dependent upon the political elite, which would use it in times of political unrest as a spearhead against radical dissent, but which never embraced its wider project for a more extensive package of moral legislation. The moral regulation projects of the second half of the Victorian period exhibited a more complex engagement with and reﬂection upon th e relationship between moral reform and philanthropy, and upon enlistin g the self-forming capacities of the widening respectable classes to effect moral reform. The contrasting lineage of the psychological disciplines was being formed during the life of the Vice Society. The medical model predictably focus ed on diagnostic work with individual patients. The question to be as ked as we turn to explore these developments is whether they succeeded in escaping from a paternalist relationship with those they worked with and thereby to penetrate more deeply into everyday life of active self-formation. THE BIRTH OF MORAL INSANITY [T]he most decided forms of human wrong-doing, and . . . the causes and nature of the moral degeneracy they evince . . . are not merely subjects for the moral philosopher and preacher, but . . . they rightly come within the scope of positive scientiﬁc research. (Maudsley, 1898: 35) During the 17th and 18th centuries insanity was predominately deﬁned in terms of a lack or derangement of reason. Conversely, sanity was unde rstood as that state of being in which an individual’s reason remained masterful over the self and its faculties, particularly over the passions. Physician s generally agreed that in order for a patient to be deemed insane, the reaso n had to be affected (Augstein, 1996; Dain and Carlson, 1962). Prior to the mid-19th century while the mad might suffer from disturbed passions medical expla- nations predominately attributed insanity to the impaired intellect. However, during the 19th century cases of madness were documented in which individuals did not display any overt mental defect. Instead they exhibited some morally offensive behaviour manifested in bizarre or outrageous conduct. This discovery gave rise to a new species of mental disease, one in w hich the diagnostic focus was upon the pathology of the individual’s moral faculty. Thus emerged ‘moral insanity’, the insanity of immorality. Medicine, both psychological and physiological, intervened and incr easingly became the designated specialism that stood watch over immoral conduct that had previously been conceived as vice or sin. Those moral ‘defects which hold the same place in the mental scale as do vices’ came to be considered as medical disorders (Magnan, 1876: 692). While ‘moral insanity’ as a mental pathology was utilized by medical writers and practitioners it still lacked a systematic description.The key role was played by James Prichard (1786–1848), an English psychiatrist and anthropologist, who ﬁrst clearly delineated moral insanity. He initially described it as a medical condition without any apparent disorder of the reasoning faculties (Prichard, 1835: 12–13). He emphasized the patient’s exercising perverted moral powers and a lack of self-governance while, at the same time, appearing mentally sound. The moral and active principles of the mind are strangely pervert ed and depraved; the power of self-government is lost or greatly impair ed; and the individual is found to be incapable . . . of conducting himself with decency and propriety in the business of life. (Prichard, 1835:6) In order to secure a diagnosis of moral insanity the patient was required to have an intact intellect: the presence of reason excluded the diagn osis of insanity. Gradually a medical model without the presence of a defect of reason became increasingly common. The diagnosis of moral insanity located the source of mental pathology in the moral faculty, not in the intel lect. The emphasis on the presence of reason coupled with the presence of exce ssive passions created a medicalized construct of vice as disease or immoral character. The word ‘moral’ in 19th-century medicine had a triple meaning such that it was wider in its scope than today. First, it was used to refer to the emotional and psychical life of an individual, to that interior depth of one’s being which was invisible yet forcefully present. Second, the term moral was concer ned with the ethical or proper conduct of citizens. And third, it referred to the inherent sociality of the self; the moral being was synonymous with the social being, meaning that individuals were conceived as inherently con stituted in and through social relations and ties. One’s morality was thus the signiﬁcation or measure of one’s loyalty, cooperativeness and dutifulness on the ethical plane of social conduct. Neo-revisionists Whitlock (1967) and Berrios (1999) argue that the term moral insanity was not concerned with anti-social disorders or unethical conduct and thus has ‘nothing to do with present-day concepts of psycho-pathic disorder’ (Whitlock, 1967: 72). Others, such as Eigen (1995), Skultans (1979) and R. Smith (1985), claim that the ‘moral’ in moral insanity referred to a perversion of ‘feelings or affections’, not immorality in the con temporary sense of the term. Readings such as these are chargeable with systematically ‘reading out’ the signiﬁcance of historical relationships between vice, moral regulation and medicine, which abound in the literature. The possibility that interior mental phenomena could be understood through two distinct orders was clearly problematic for psychiatrists attempting to explain how rationality could exist alongside pathological morality. In 1857, in his lectures on moral insanity, Kitching elaborated a theory of the separation of the rational and moral which, although in use for two decades, had not been clearly articulated. He argued that the internal mental activity of individuals could be explained by positing two separate faculties: the intellectual and the moral faculty. All those powers of the mind by which we maintain our positions as rational creatures . . . are intellectual powers. . . . But we feel that we have other powers . . . designated by the term ‘moral and instinct ive faculties.’ They are moral, because they preside over the regulation of our conduct towards others, and determine our sentiments and fee lings. (Kitching, 1857a: 336) Arguing that no direct relationship existed between these faculties resulted in a significant development in medical conceptions of moral character and health that considerably expanded the reach of the medical conception of madness. It introduced an understanding of ‘character ’ that went beyond reason and rationality to focus upon the ‘moral perceptions and sensibilities which are necessary for the formation of a great a nd useful character’ (Kitching, 1857a: 336). The emphasis upon the moral capacity made it possible for a sane subject to be deemed insane and a mora lly insane subject to be rational. The positing of a distinct moral faculty was incorporated into the general practice of psychological medicine. The next crucial step was the contention that vices such as crime, prostitution and pauperism were evils held to be hereditary in origin. Anti-social conduct that contributed to social disruption was identified as a form of disease. With the formation of the doctrine of moral insanity the passions were no lo nger deemed secondary to reason, but instead occupied a central place in the epistemic grid of madness. Diagnoses of moral insanity occupied a continuum of severity where in the mildest cases were identiﬁed as exhibiting eccentricity. Other variants consisted of ‘simple viciousness to those extreme manifestations which pass far beyond the bounds of what anyone would call vice’ (Maudsley, 1884: 285). Moral insanity affected ‘the innermost nucleus of the individuali tyin its emotional, ethical and moral relations’ (Krafft-Ebing, 1992: 622).Skae described the morally insane as having ‘morbid, and uncontrolla ble, and self- destroying appetites’ and becoming ‘the children of impulse, reckless of personal respect, regardless of the value of money, and scorning even decency itself’ (Skae, 1858: 777, 782). Anne Digby has remarked that the broad deﬁnition and symptomatology of the category provided an open invitation to designate madness, resulting in mad-doctors diagnosing the disease with ‘surprising self-conﬁdence’ (1985: 83). Krafft-Ebing argued that moral insanity could be recognized by impulsive characteristics such as vagabondage, theft, alcoholic and sexual exce ss which were all due to perverted instincts, particularly the sexual instinct (1992: 625). In a clinical case study, he describes a morally insane female servant as ‘lazy, mendacious, chasing after men, and prone to prostitution’. Her conduct caused ‘the respectable family’ who employed her to dismiss her be cause of ‘her ﬁlth, negligence, laziness, bad manners, brutality, and sense less wasting of money’ (Krafft-Ebing, 1992: 627). One major interpretive framework for explaining moral insanit y was the theory of progressive hereditary degeneration ﬁrst advanced by B. A. Morel (1857). Moral insanity came to be viewed as a speciﬁc form of degeneration; in this context several leading experts adopted Morel’s prin ciples of hered- ity. While discussions on psychiatric classiﬁcations in general have be encommented on by historians such as Constance McGovern (1985), Andrew Scull (1989, 1993), Edward Shorter (1997), and Elaine Showalter (1985), curiously little critical attention has been placed upon the cultural and historical signiﬁcance of the emergence of moral insanity.Towards the end of the 19th century, moral insanity was alternatively referred to as ‘moral imbecility’, signiﬁed by those individuals who exhibited an ethical and aesthetic defect, and an inclination to immoral conduct (Barr, 1895; Kerlin, 1887). Kerlin’s discussion relies on a series of cases: an ‘incipient prostitute’, a burglar, ‘a hereditary religious hypocrite and egoist . . . a conﬁrmed juvenile tramp and incipient conﬁdence man’ (1887: 400). ‘Whether we call these cases examples of moral imbecility or give them some other name, we must recognize t hat there is a depravity which is the result of heredity or some imperfe ct development of the nervous system’ (Wood cited in Kerlin, 1887: 400). Dr Zebulon Reed Brockway, founder of the Elmira Reformatory in New York, claimed to have discovered among the prisoners only 6 per cent in whom the moral faculty was normal and preferred to use for them the term ‘moral imbecile’. The distaste for the term ‘moral insanity’ provided the chief impetus for the diagnostic category of ‘moral imbecility’ which for some psychiatrists provided medical nomenclature with a more neutral and less provocative epithet, but the psychiatric conviction that moral abnormality was a scientiﬁc psychological disorder persisted, despite these terminological quarrels. Thus a medical concern was maintained with a class of individuals who lacked moral and social self-control (Kerlin, 1887: 404). As Hughes noted, ‘those who deny the possibility of moral insanity make a classiﬁcation of moral imbecility, concessions which logically debar all opposition to moral insanity’ (1882: 72; original emphasis). DEGENERACY AND VICE In a period when science was making sustained attempts to determine the laws of heredity, Morel advanced the doctrine of hereditary degeneration. In the second half of the 19th century theories of heredity became a prominent disourse not only in medicine and psychiatry but also in anthropology, biology, sociology and criminology. The notion of degeneracy provided a theory of hereditary moral pathology (Pick, 1989). Morel, himself a devout Catholic, viewed the stigmata of degeneracy as ‘a fall from grace’ resulting from the use of various ‘poisons’ such as hashish, alcohol and opium that resulted in a progressive physical and moral deterioration (Bynum, 1984; Rosenburg, 1974). While it was in vogue by mid-century, the degeneration hypothesis made its mark most forcefully from 1870 and was used well into the early 20th century (Dain and Carlson, 1962). Morel’s theory of degeneration was widely used to explain the aetiology of moral insanity and how the same virtues or vices could persist within one family. Concerned with the dangers of vice, Morel approved of Prichard’s account of moral insanity. The common assumption that the degenerate was a marked departure from the normal and tending, more or less rapidly, towards extinctio n medicalized a notion of ‘the fall from grace’ in which the progeny of degenerates exhibited a progressive moral and physical deterioration. This assumption generated hypotheses that certain social groups such as prostitutes, criminals, paupers and the insane were morally defective and represented a regression in human evolution. Degenerates were not, however, ‘always crimi nals, prostitutes, anarchists, and pronounced lunatics; they are often authors and artists . . . who satisfy their unhealthy impulses’ (Nordau, 1898: vii). Talbot argued that degenerate morality could occur in the scientist, the able lawyer, the skilled administrator, the mathematician, or the great artist and poet (Talbot, 1984[1898]: 315). A central role was played in degeneracy theory by the theologically laden dictum of ‘the sins of the father’; the signiﬁcance being that all were vulnerable, potential bearers or receivers of degeneracy: ‘each in dividual, each family, each nation may take either an upward course of evolution or a downward course of degeneration’ (Maudsley, 1884: 238). Drawing on Morel, Max Nordau argued that The clearest notion we can form of degeneracy is to regard it as a morbid deviation from an original type. This deviation, even if, at the outset, it was ever so slight contained transmissible elements of such a nature that anyone bearing in him the germs becomes more and more incapable of fulﬁlling his functions in the world; and mental progress . . . ﬁnds itself menaced also in his descendants. (1898: 16) Persons perceived as deviating from the moral norm thus became the proper subjects of medicine. Degeneracy theory was widely employed by social purity activists in late Victorian Britain and the United States. The central rhetorical attack was upon otherwise ‘respectable gentlemen’ who contracted venereal diseases from prostitutes and introduced the seed of degeneration into their family line (Hunt, 1999: 128–30). Moral degenerates were not simply a ‘variation of nature’, but constituted a dissolution and whole-scale transformation of ‘the race’. Degeneration meant literally the ‘undoing of a kind . . . used exclusively to denote a change from a higher to a lower kind ’ (Maudsley, 1884: 240; original emphasis). Theorized as a transformation from normal to abnormal, moral degeneration was the process through which ‘an asocial or anti-social kind’ is formed (Maudsley, 1884: 241). Maudsley’s equation of the terms ‘anti-social’ and immoral is signiﬁcant in that it facilitated an expansionary logic in which not only individuals but whole classes, races and nations could become subject to degenerate tendencies. The 19th-century medical understandings of the notion of the moral had several related connotations which help to contextualize the emergence of ‘anti-social’ concerns within psychiatry. First, the moral referred to the interior life-world such that the feelings, affections and sentiments were considered intrinsic to and inseparable from moral character. Second, the term moral was imbued with Christian conceptions of virtuous conduct as the primary motor force stimulating ethical self-governance. Finally, it referred to the inherent social ontology of the self such that individuals were deemed moral insofar as they were essentially social. Understood as intrinsically constituted through non-negotiable social relations, individuals were perceived as morally normal inasmuch as they recognized their social responsibilities and obligations accessed through their conscience. Maudsley’s use, therefore, of ‘anti-social’ to describe the degeneration of the morally insane is illuminating in providing a socially deﬁned view of a morality irreducible to biologisms or psychocentric conceptions of moral character as an individualistic phenomenon. The designation of moral insanity as a form of degeneration included symptoms such as a failure to recognize the rights of others, a derangement of social sense, remorselessness, shamelessness in transgressing moral codes, lack of repentance for perverse conduct. Krafft-Ebing argued that the most striking features consisted of moral insensibility, lack of moral judgement and absence of ethical ideas. Although morally insane individuals were conceived as able to understand moral rules, some congenital defect, poor habits or a physiological disorder caused in them an insatiable immoral impulse. ‘The ethical defect in these individuals of inferior organization in the end renders them incapable of maintaining a place in society’ (Krafft-Eb ing, 1992: 623). Most experts on moral insanity followed Herbert Spencer’s evolutionary approach to understanding social progress and morality. Mauds ley, Tuke and others postulated that because the moral faculty was the last to evolve and the most sophisticated human capacity, it was also the most liable to deterioration or failure. Higher moral feelings were thought to be acquired gradually by cultivation passed between generations; their loss being ‘the most striking symptom of insanity caused by self-abuse’ (Maudsley, 1868: 155). Because the higher levels of cerebral development were treated as the locus of moral control, the lack of self-governance was deemed to be the result of a ‘lower level of evolution’ (Tuke, 1891: 21–2). Moral insanity was thus conceived as a disease of civilized peoples. Morality, hailed as the highest accomplishment of ‘civilization’ and ‘progress’, was accordingly not to be found among ‘savage’ races. The development of moral powers and sentiments was an achievement solely of the ‘superior’ white races. One had ﬁrst to possess a moral sense before this faculty could degenerate into disease (Rimke, forthcoming). Maudsley summarizes this process: As it is chieﬂy in the degeneration of the social sentiments that th e symptoms of moral insanity declare themselves, it is plain that th e most typical forms of the disease can only be met with in those who have had some social cultivation. (1867: 313) The understanding of moral insanity was profoundly inﬂuenced by evolutionary thought, which proliferated in many forms, most of them either hostile to Darwin’s version or, while paying lip-service there to, departing radically from it (Bowler, 1983). Indeed it was not the evolutionism of Darwin, but the Lamarckian version that was most inﬂuential in the debates around moral insanity and degeneracy. Lamarck posited the evolutionary mechanism as the transmission of culturally acquired moral and physical characteristics between generations; in this version evolutio nism was compatible with the doctrine that the sins of the fathers were visited upon their progeny. Degeneration theory expressed the growing fears concerning the primitive within civilization and the potential dangers of evolution descending into an uncontrollable and regressive movement (Dollimore, 1996). Smith demonstrates how the concern with ‘a loss of inhibition’ permeated 19th-century medicine and the development of socio-evolutionary theories of social order and human difference which naturalized socially constituted hierarchies. The scientization of medico-moral concepts such as ‘inh ibition’ both legitimated and reinforced the belief in inherited traits, conduct patterns and structured social positions of class, race and gender which ‘rei nterpreted human evil –aggression, lust, stupidity– as the unavoidable conse quences of an animal descent’ (R. Smith, 1992: 174). As a disease of the moral faculty moral insanity was linked to the qual ities of character and temperament. In the 19th century medical discourses we re replete with discussions on the cultivation or inheritance of cha racter as a source for the transmission of immorality: In place of difﬁdence and self-restraint we see exhibited a bold an d presumptuous address; in place of reﬁned manners and modest conversation, coarse behaviour and indelicate allusions; in place of chaste and decent conduct, indecency and even open lasciviousness. (Maudsley, 1884: 265–6) The derangement of character was explained by Jordan as the result of early degeneration of nervous organization (1890:9). Defects of the will were found in weak or deranged characters and resulted in an absence of self-mastery which became the primary symptom of moral insanity. On the side of the will, the ethic and intellectual defect manifests itself in the complete absence of power of self-direction and control. In general, these degenerates are noticeable for their lack of mental tone and laziness, which are overcome only for the satisfaction of their immoral or criminal instincts. (Krafft-Ebing, 1992: 624) Defects of character were thus conceived as a medical disorder resulting from defects of an interior moral sensibility. The onset of degeneracy was characterized by the successive peeling-away of the fine textures of moral sentiments. Maudsley outlined the stages of the descent into degeneration as initially due to insufficient exercise and improper use of moral and volitional powers so that the unchecked satisfaction of passion introduced a deterioration of character in the first generation. In the second generation a mental derangement emerged that was manifested in defects in character that fell short of madness or crime. The third generation descended into moral imbecility with or without intellectualimpairment. Finally the lineage was extinguished through sterility or impotence. Maudsley’s typology allowed room for modifications over the generations through countervailing influences such as strong moral training, but the medical lesson was patently clear: the acquired habits of vice in one generation resulted in deficiency in succeeding generations (1884: 248). If no direct parental link could be established ancestral forces and influences were evoked as a causal explanation. Magnan argued that it was impossible to understand the patient’s disease without taking account of hereditary background: It cannot be understood if studied by itself. . . . We must of necessity therefore, turn back to the antecedent history of these patients, and we shall then find that they have shown peculiarities of character at various periods of life before being driven to drink. (1876: 693) Eccentricities were considered as indications of a deep-seated mental disorder which could be ascertained by examining the patient’s biography. Symptoms were to be examined, not in isolation, but in the context of the entire life history and its intersection with familial morality. Children who were the unfortunate descendants of ‘a family in which insanity or epilepsy or some form or other of mental degeneracy exists . . . are the antisocial upshots of a process of degeneration in the line of theirdescent’ (Maudsley, 1884: 246–7). Krafft-Ebing argued that ‘the monstrosity of man’s mental make-up’ in cases of moral insanity necessitated strict clinical criteria for diagnosis; the decisive pointers indicating moral insanity required evidence of degeneracy in the parents, and only then was the physician to examine the patient for the existence of anatomical or functional signs of degeneracy (1992: 626). The moral quality of both parents was paramount to the production of virtuous children. ‘Depraved . . . or drunken parents, cannot transmit a healthy organization to their descendants’ (Kitching,1857b: 454). If any predecessor had suffered from insanity, all extended familial members were at risk of moral pathology: It is a long known fact that drunkards, for instance, have idiot children in a far larger proportion than sober people. Such facts cannot be either too generally known, or too strongly impressed on the public mind: they show the tremendous amount of responsibility which attaches to the thoughtless votary of sensual or wicked pleasure. (Kitching, 1857b: 454) A ‘good life’ was construed as the result of a perfectly balanced physical constitution whereas a ‘bad life’ was the product of a defective hereditary organization. Moral dispositions were thus somatically predetermined. Most morally insane were condemned at birth, not simply metaphysically, but scientifically in terms of their corporeal heritage. Even before birth, the individual was predestined, not only to mental health or disease, but to vice or virtue. At birth, one was predisposed, by ‘hereditary taints’, to a corporeal constitution inextricably entangled with the moral character. There was a vogue for tracing the family histories of degenerates. Degenerate families, such as ‘the Jukes’, ‘the Chesters’ and ‘the Kallikaks’, acted as widely publicized warnings of the dangers of degeneracy and provided a moral parable of the hereditary evils of vice and the abominable consequences of ungoverned appetites. The role of habits in health discourses provided a prominent theme. Elizabeth Blackwell, for example, argued that the relation between habit and heredity involved powerful physiological factors that were key to preventing or accelerating degeneration both individually and nationally (1894: 4, 59). The ability to form virtuous habits, and the power of transmitting to off-spring the tendencies produced by good habits such as personal chastity, promoted not only personal health, but also the moral health of the nation (Blackwell, 1894: 59, 62). The moral panic over degeneracy provided a hybridized moral and medical warning of the dangers of loose habits and inadequate self-governance. The theory of hereditarian degeneration also provided a scientific discourse for legitimating the maintenance and reproduction of gender roles, particularly for women. Women who defied the social prescriptions of the good mother and the dutiful wife were believed to place their children’s moral future at risk. [C]oncerning all the evil passions, and especially licentiousness, let no regrets ever darken a mother’s life when she sees her son a libertine, or her daughter an amarosa. She can prevent such disasters if she will; and if she will not, great will be her responsibility. (Williamson, 1898:369–70) As ‘mothers of the nation’ those mothers who engaged in vices were scientized as endangering not only the moral health of their offspring, but the entire happiness and health of the race and nation. Thus if a mother associated with ‘low, base, unworthy society, reads sensual literature, and delights in voluptuous scenes and licentious practices. . . . the child she bears will as surely be a libertine if male, or a wanton if female, as it is sure to be born’ (Williamson, 1898: 359). A wide array of medical treatises and advice manuals accordingly warned of the dangers of imprudent maternal conduct. Moral education, training and virtuous habits were thought to counter the risk of degeneration by encouraging morally directed self-governance and temperance. Moral education and discipline, however, were rarely regarded as a successful means for treating the morally insane. The best remedy for the occurrence and propagation of moral insanity, typically prognosticized as incurable, was believed to be sterilization, confinement, or laws prohibiting the marriage of moral degenerates. PSYCHIATRY AND THE GOVERNANCE OF THE LIBERAL INDIVIDUAL The doctrine of moral insanity arose from an attempt to reconcile theological oncerns to sustain the notion of the corrupt and immaterial soul with a burgeoning medical science. The notion of ungovernable excessive passions as constitutive of a moral disease, as an abnormal phenomenon that could be mastered by a rationalizing science, was an attempt to govern what was viewed as the increasing prevalence of vice due to the temptations of civilization. By the end of the 19th century, crime, prostitution and sexual perversions, moral insanity, and inebriety all constituted forms of psychological ‘ethical degeneracy’ of the person. The doctrine of moral insanity provides one particularly cogent example of an effective instance in which the medical community positioned itself as an active moral police force in the growing efforts to govern and remedy a ‘decaying social world’ through regulatory struggles to govern the passions and appetites of citizens. In this way the diseases of the moral faculty could be traced to a conjunction between physical and somatic causes thereby justifying their position within medical nosologies. The mastery and success of a curative medical science provided evidence that its expertise could be effectively exercised in moral matters. Should the same industry and ingenuity, which have produced the triumphs of medicine over diseases and death, be applied to moral sciences, it is highly probable, that most of those baneful vices, which deform the human breast, and convulse the nations of the earth, might be banished from the world. (Rush, 1839: 24–5) The construction of moral insanity as a form of degeneration needs to be understood in two ways: first, as the first medical attempt to create a medical model of vice as pathology; and second, as a concerted effort by medical authorities to promote a unique claim to a privileged place in efforts to regulate vice. It also provided medical psychologists and psychiatrists with the authority to govern in seemingly expedient ways conducive for ‘the greater good’. As a body of discourses, medicine legitimated and encoded morality through its status as science. As a means of constituting ‘the Other’, degeneration was increasingly applied to explain psychopathic and other socially objectionable conduct and to secure the appropriation of deviance by medical knowledge. The stigmata of the degenerate was the medical analogue for the human race’s unremitting potential to fall from grace (Gilman, 1985: 192). The miseries and deterioration of the human race could be explained scientifically, and therefore be prevented. The endeavor to understand heredity and the transmission of human traits intergenerationally was one of the ways in which natural laws of moral character were incorporated into medicine. The invention of moral insanity was, moreover, an attempt to govern the population through a hybrid knowledge: a scientific knowledge which maintained Christian values and rule by administering to the morally ruined. Rush was explicit in valorizing this function of medicine: The doctrine of the influence of physical causes on morals is happily calculated to beget charity towards the failings of our fellow creatures. Our duty to practise this virtue is enforced by motives drawn from science, as well as from the precepts of Christianity. (1839: 19) As secular superintendents of the public soul, medical psychologists and physicians increasingly exercised their cultural authority and expertise by offering scientific definitions of vice as abnormality and degeneration. The ‘business of the physician’ was to ‘reclaim mankind from vice’ (Rush cited in Takaki, 1979: 23). Medicine, for Rush, included more than simply caring for the body; it also served as a surrogate ministry of the soul and morals: ‘Maynot . . . a medicine be discovered which shall improve, or alter the diseased state of the moral faculty’ (Rush cited in Takaki, 1979: 22). Psychiatrists asserted their expertise and demanded wider public recognition thereof based on the general argument that society required a remedy for its ills and only medical experts had the scientific knowledge to achieve such ends. Through their medical expertise, physicians provided a plethora of scientific narratives to account for the increasing moral degeneracy in society thus operating as social champions of ‘goodness’, ‘normalcy’ and the moral health of the nation. The injection of morality and ethical values into medical discourses involved a concern for public health, advice and education on the social evils of vice. Physicians thus came to act as the custodians of the collective soul and of the social body. As a result, vice and immorality were firmly placed within the domain of medical science which normalized and naturalized the medicalization of morality in western society. CONCLUSION : HYBRID MORAL REGULATION At first glance it might seem that we have recounted two entirely separate moments in the history of 19th-century moral regulation. It is certainly true that the worthy moralists of the Vice Society and the energetic founders of the psychological sciences had no direct contact with each other. We were anxious to detect such links if only at the level of interpersonal acquaintance between the participants; although it would have made our task easier we were not surprised that we discovered no such links. Yet this absence of direct connections strengthens our commitment to the contention that the radically dissimilar developments exemplify a deep hybridity that so often marks the uneven and contingent historical process. The focus on hybridity constitutes a radical challenge to linear historical narratives that are characterized by a sequential movement through a series of stages that move events from the past towards the present or from a ‘tra- ditional’ past to a ‘modern’ present.15 If our account were to be cast in this form we would be arguing that the Vice Society represented a traditional attempt to impose a moral code whereas the discovery of moral insanity represented a break with the past and produced a medical displacement of theologically grounded morality. This is not the case we seek to establish. We reject an approach that poses the question in terms of whether one development was an ‘advance’ over another; for example, we decline to pass judgement on whether imprisonment or confinement was more or less coercive, just as we reject the popular claim of ‘social control’ theory that they are merely changing forms of an ongoing coercion. The approach we advocate locates development within a plurality of trajectories which periodically collide, confront each other, or, at other times, interact and even merge. The means of realizing this approach is to focus, as we have done, on the way in which issues are problematized in practices, discursive and non-discursive, which cause something to enter the game of truth and falsity, and thus become objects of inquiries such as moral reflection, scientific knowledge, or political analysis. The two projects we have explore exemplify two problematizations of mental-moral-social disorder of the 19th century. Behind the evident differences between the moral regulation discourses of the Vice Society and the psychiatric debate on moral insanity there persist the shifting problematizations of anxieties about moral disorder. The lines of connection between the two sets of problematization are radically confirmed when at the very end of the century the two strands become dramatically united: a solid alliance was formed, both in the United States and in Britain, between moral reformers and medical moralizers to form a variety of ‘social and moral hygiene’ movements. In the United States it was to take its most developed form in Dr Prince Morrow’s Society of Sanitary and Moral Prophylaxis formed in 1905. In England the National Council of Public Morals, formed in 1904, later became the Association for Moral and Social Hygiene. This movement was a self-conscious alliance between sections of the medical profession and of psychiatrists concerned with sexual morality and sexually transmitted diseases who joined with moral reformers, now heavily influenced by ‘first wave’ feminism, which like its male counterparts drew its inspiration from the evangelical currents that had been surging through Protestantism. Their main target was the suppression of prostitution and the imposition of a single restrictive standard of sexual morality for both men and women. This was organized around a confluence between a heavily theological moral discourse and a medical discourse replete with imagery of national decline consequent on the degeneration resulting from the moral debility caused by the discursively linked ‘feeblemindedness’ and venereal diseases. The hybridity of these configurations of moral regulation projects is evident in the way in which they carried forwards elements from the two earlier traditions while at the same time effecting shifts in the combination of elements growing out of the earlier problematizations.18 Thus the concept of ‘moral insanity’ was expanded into a more general concern with its organizing concept of ‘degeneracy’ now broadened into the new master discourse of eugenics. At the same time the discourses of the ‘social purity’ strands had acquired a strongly feminist dimension. Immorality was no longer a general anxiety about sexual excess, but a specifically gendered discourse. It was a discourse that took two interchangeable forms. In one, male lust became the primary moralized target, while in the other, it was the prostitute who seduced men and thereby spread venereal diseases. There is, however, no doubt that enforcement practices continued to impact most heavily on female prostitutes. Our study has demonstrated the disparate lines of development of psychological and moralizing engagement with diverse populations that generated anxieties about the disorder consequent upon both individual and collective forms of problematic excess. There was no linear development, for example, from theological to secular moral governance, nor was there an untroubled advance of medical knowledge. Influential though the discourses organized around moral insanity were, they never succeeded in establishing a coherent or comprehensive doctrine. However, moral insanity did not simply vanish from the psychiatric imaginary. Rather it was absorbed into new clinical categories by the end of the 19th century. This can be witnessed, for example, in Kock’s ‘psychopathic inferiorities’, Albrecht’s ‘amoral syndrome’, Bleuler’s ‘moral oligophrenia’, Scholz’s ‘moral anaesthesia’ and Kahn’s ‘moral feeblemindedness’, all of which continued to identify sexual aberrations, shamelessness, eccentricities and ethical deformities as symptomatic ofmental disease. Not until 1950 did Schneider warn his professional colleagues that descriptors of psychopathy inherited from 19th-century medicine should be avoided because they had ‘a social rather than a clinical ring’ (1958:126). Thus, despite changes in terminology, classifications and an ever-expanding list of symptoms, the doctrine has an irrefutable relation to contemporary psychiatric discourses on ‘anti-social’ personalities with their heavy-handed focus on social and moral transgressions (McCord and McCord, 1964: 24; Craft, 1965: 8; Leaff, 1978: 80; Elliott, 1978: 147). While no uncontested and unified doctrine of moral insanity was ever advanced, it did provide the springboard for the emergence of the relatively stable and persistent category of ‘personality disorders’ within psychiatry over the last hundred years. Similarly the attempts to enforce moral codes grounded in theology did not disappear but persistently reemerged and were reconfigured within new discursive linkages.

vectors.text: Almas encerradas, cuerpos al desnudo: sexualidad, erotismo y feminidad en la edad victoriana resumen A través de este escrito nos adentraremos en el contexto histórico y social de la edad victoriana y de algunos de sus autores. Analizaremos temas inherentes a la sexualidad, sus leyes y prohibiciones. En contraste con el progreso tecnológico que experimentó la sociedad británica durante el siglo XIX, la época victoriana se caracterizó por un puritanismo exagerado, una tremenda represión sexual y la infravaloración de la mujer, transformada en responsable de todos los males sociales. Moral que fue duramente criticada por algunos de sus contemporáneos, como los escritores Oscar Wilde y Bernard Shaw, que reflejaron en sus obras la mediocridad y la estrechez de miradas de aquella sociedad. Por lo tanto, a lo largo de este artículo, examinaremos leyes represivas y restrictivas que dan crédito a tal afirmación. La dualidad de la época victoriana será el tema y núcleo principal del estudio, en relación con el contexto histórico, social y político de la sociedad inglesa durante el periodo en cuestión. Las conexiones literarias entre transformación psicológica, dualidad y carácter del personaje literario, entendido en sentido genérico o bien como un yo literario, serán determinantes, pues nos remiten a las concepciones de los autores en torno a la personalidad dualista como reelaboración o como metáfora de la existencia humana y de la vida en su transformación material. Los resultados de esta investigación, a lo largo de sus detalladas cinco secciones y su conclusión, nos inducen a creer que la victoriana fue una sociedad plenamente dual, donde, por un lado, se emanaron leyes represivas de género y, por el otro, se dio total desenfreno al libertinaje. introducción El objeto de este trabajo es presentar los resultados de una investigación en torno a las normas morales de la sociedad victoriana, para tejer y entrelazar una serie de importantes antecedentes y referencias históticas y sociales de la época en cuestión. Entre los principales rasgos de la sociedad victoriana emergen estrechos prejuicios y grandes planes imperiales, desde el punto de vista político. Intelectualmente hablando, sobresale la creencia en el progreso y la negación del pecado original, aunque se adoptan posturas maniqueas, como aquella de la eterna lucha entre el bien y el mal. Pero, más allá de eso, la incorporación al análisis filosófico-literario del principio nihilista de “Dios ha muerto” de Friedrich Nietzsche constituye un acierto por evidenciar metafóricamente la ruptura de los cimientos del conocimiento y de la moral de la sociedad occidental: se trata de la muerte de los valores que hasta ese momento le otorgaban un sentido a la experiencia humana. Sin embargo, esta muerte no ha de entenderse como una forma de irreligiosidad o ateísmo, en el sentido estricto, sino más bien como la emergencia, tras la muerte de Dios, del artista humano como ser creador, o alter deus, que viene a ocupar el espacio que dejó vacante aquel Dios desaparecido. Con esta imagen significativa de la muerte de Dios, se restaura la comprensión tradicional de la cultura como confirmación de la posición de superioridad del ser humano. Es así que el núcleo y el interés del presente artículo comienza por formular el diagnóstico de la patología moral que subyace en la época victoriana, en los temas y tramas más característicos de dicho periodo, para desembocar en el análisis de la dimensión semántica de las palabras y la función comunicativa de las imágenes, como vehículo para el razonamiento filosófico, en términos de ética y estética; pero también en función de una profunda reconstrucción del conocimiento del ser humano, de su psiquis, de su sexualidad y de los límites de su libertad individual. En el primer apartado serán analizados algunos rasgos de la medicina y de la psicología victoriana, a través de personajes ilustres de la época que aportaron cambios relevantes a la manera de pensar de tal sociedad. Tema principal del segundo son las leyes de enfermedades contagiosas emanadas por el Gobierno británico en la segunda parte del siglo XIX. Los asesinatos de Whitechapel, famoso lugar londinense donde, en los últimos meses de 1888, tuvieron lugar cinco espantosos feminicidios, serán mencionados en el acápite tres. Las probables conexiones entre tales hechos y personajes de la sociedad victoriana serán clave para entender la dualidad de este periodo histórico en la sociedad británica. Antes de llegar a las conclusiones, haremos un alto en el camino para dar detalles acerca del concepto de feminidad de la época y las leyes represivas y restrictivas contra la prostitución y la homosexualidad. Medicina y psicología sexual victoriana Nuestro viaje comienza por personajes ilustres como el escritor científico y novelista canadiense Grant Allen (1848-1899), destacado defensor de la teoría de la evolución y divulgador del darwinismo; el sexólogo Havelock Ellis (1859-1939), médico y activista social; y el poeta y filósofo socialista −además de activista homosexual británico− Edward Carpenter (1844-1929); quienes intentaron lograr cambios drásticos en este campo a través de una extensa revisión del cristianismo, el capitalismo y la historia humana en su conjunto. Por cierto, en la década de 1890, se lleva a cabo una fuerte emancipación sexual que tiende a coincidir con el sentimiento antivictoriano prevaleciente en la Primera Guerra Mundial de los años posteriores. Como observa Mason,la época de la oposición sexual de Grant Allen es la más grandiosa. Carpenter era partidario de reconocer una tercera o sexualidad intermedia, que él mismo, a finales del siglo XIX, definió como Urnings, proveniente de Urania, cuyo significado es paraíso. Singular es el caso de Havelock Ellis, quien se casó con la escritora y luchadora por los derechos de las mujeres, Edith Lees, a la edad de 32 años. Hay que mencionar que no fue un matrimonio convencional; él padeció de impotencia sexual hasta los 60 años y ella era abiertamente lesbiana. La relación “abierta” que los dos vivieron es tema central de su biografía titulada My life, un libro en donde nos cuenta que “poco después de la edad de treinta años, concebí en privado la idea de escribir un relato íntimo de mi propia vida”. Un dato curioso es cómo justo a los 60 años, el escritor tuvo una erección mientras estaba siendo observado por una mujer, en el acto de orinar. Ellis es considerado un pionero de la psicología sexual que, bajo una concepción naturalista y racional, se propuso explicar la conducta sexual humana, alejado de toda la estigmatización de la rígida moral de la Inglaterra victoriana, donde la prostitución callejera y la transmisión de enfermedades sexuales era algo bastante común y donde proliferaban los burdeles, lugares en los cuales, según Foucault, “el sexo salvaje tendría derecho a formas de lo real. En todos los demás lugares el puritanismo moderno habría impuesto su triple decreto de prohibición, inexistencia y mutismo”. También existía una activa estigmatización, criminalización y persecución de toda conducta sexual que se alejara de una relación heterosexual con finalidades de procreación. Croizer comenta que la sodomía o buggery, independientemente de que se diera de forma homosexual o heterosexual, podía llegar a ser castigada hasta con la pena de muerte. Asimismo, existían múltiples tabúes en relación con la masturbación, de la cual se decía que podía producir deterioro en el desarrollo físico e intelectual de los niños. Por otro lado, la sexualidad de la mujer se entendía únicamente como pasiva, con fines reproductivos y al servicio de la del hombre. Pese a perseguir y condenar la homosexualidad masculina, el lesbianismo no era perseguido por ignorar su existencia. Por este hecho y más desigualdades, Charlot y Marx la apodan la sociedad dual. El doctor William Acton (1813-1875) fue un cirujano especializado en trastornos genitourinarios y enfermedades venéreas. Cada vez más, su interés se extendió a los problemas sociales detrás de dichas enfermedades. Acerca de la creciente prostitución en la época victoriana, Acton identifica los problemas médicos y sociales que rodean a las mujeres y los hombres involucrados en el comercio, antes de hacer recomendaciones sobre formas de introducir regulaciones. En un momento en que la prostitución eraa menudo mal entendida, sensacionalizada o demonizada, el trabajo del doctor Acton se consideraba medido y compasivo, desafiando los estereotipos negativos y pidiendo que se pusiera fin a la clasificaciónde las mujeres como proscritas. Rechazó la opinión popular de que las mujeres elegían la prostitución porque eran innatamente pecaminosas y poseían una sensualidad antinatural. En cambio, Acton destacó el rango de condiciones sociales que llevaron a las mujeres al comercio, incluyendo la angustia y el hambre. Sin embargo, la dualidad de William Acton se reveló más tarde al apoyar la Ley de Enfermedades Contagiosas (Contagious Diseases Acts),que efectivamente criminalizó a todas las mujeres que se sabía o sospechaba trabajaban como prostitutas. A tal propósito, Ellis hace referencia a él, con respecto a su vil opinión de insensibilidad sexual femenina, afirmando que la de Acton es una falacia venerable. Mora nos habla de la relación de apreciación mutua entre Ellis y Freud, que también se conocieron. Es sabido que ambos autores empezaron a estar al corriente de los trabajos y aportaciones del otro, siendo digno de mencionar el hecho de que Freud adoptara de Ellis los términos de autoerotismo y narcisismo al señalar que: Cabe destacar que en octubre de 1898 Ellis publicó su trabajo titulado Auto-erotism: A psychological study en el volumen 19 de la reconocida revista The Alienist and Neurologist –fundada y editada por Charles Hamilton (1839-1916) entre los años 1880 y 1916–. Este trabajo despertó el interés de Freud sobre la figura de Ellis. Es importante recordar que Havelock Ellis puede ser considerado también como un hombre completamente adelantado a sus tiempos, siendo precursor y pionero en la defensa de la eutanasia y del aborto, llegando a manifestar que ni siquiera el Estado podía tener más derecho que los individuos a forzar a una mujer en contra de su voluntad. Entre otros hechos por recordar, señalamos unas líneas de su obra The Psychology of Sex, de 1933: We may not know exactly what sex is, but we do not know that it is mutable, with the possibility of one sex being changed into the other sex, that its frontiers are often uncertain, and that there are many stages between a complete male and a complete female. Es posible que no sepamos exactamente qué es el sexo, pero no sabemos que es mutable, con la posibilidad de que un sexo se transforme en el otro, que sus fronteras son a menudo inciertas y que hay muchas etapas entre un varón completo y una hembra completa. Ellis y Carpenter contradicen radicalmente la idea freudiana según la cual la anatomía es el destino del ser. Esta teoría de una tercera identidad sexual será un gran atractivo para el desarrollo de la estética feminista de Virginia Woolf, en la preparación de su novela Orlando: A Biography, donde el protagonista tiene la última palabra sobre su identidad sexual. Según Mason, escritores como Ellis y Carpenter eran radicales sexuales de tiempo completo. Hubo otros escritores que se unieron a los rangos emancipacionistas esporádicamente en las décadas de 1880 y 1890, sobre temas particulares.12 De Edward Carpenter destacamos la idealización del amor homosexual de las obras de Platón, bastante popular entre la comunidad homosexual de la época victoriana, y las continuas alusiones al amor griego como un código oculto al tratar su orientación sexual. Oscar Wilde hizo incesantemente referencia al “regreso al ideal heleno”. Carpenter era también un amante del nudismo que él veía como un símbolo de unión con la naturaleza. Desde allí, comenzó a cultivar una forma de pensamiento filosófico que se enfocaba en la sencillez de la vida, la necesidad de vivir al aire libre, una forma de vestir racional y una dieta ovolácteo vegetariana, en pleno respeto de los seres del mundo animal.
